Hi Zack,

You fail to mention all the dishwashers, laundry equipment, refri=
gerators, stoves, ovens, and ice machines in every home.=A0 All the medical=
 equipment in the hospitals. 
These devices have all come to use computer b=
oards in them.=A0 

We have frequent storms here on the Texas Gulf Coast.=
=A0 I can't begin to tell you how barbaric we become with the extended loss=
 of electricity.=A0 Radiation would be far worse and more wide spread. 

Re=
gards,
Jon in Texas=A0

--- On Mon, 10/5/09, Zack Widup <w9sz.zack@...=
m> wrote:

=A0




    
                  It depends on what radia=
tion you're talking about, =A0the electronic equipment and what it's made o=
f. 
=A0
EMP (electromagnetic pulse) generated at the time of a nuclear deto=
nation will probably wipe out any solid-state electronics that isn't heavil=
y shielded against it. Alpha and beta particles could affect some electroni=
cs that managed to survive an EMP.

=A0
The older stuff like RTL and TTL lo=
gic is probably not going to be much affected by the alpha and beta radiati=
on. CMOS devices, sensitive to static discharges, would be next.=A0VLSI chi=
ps have the greatest chance of being affected (read: home computers). Vacuu=
m tube circuits would hardly=A0be affected at all, even by EMP.


Strange t=
hat some of our oldest devices would be the last to go.
:-)
=A0
Zack=A0

=
=A0
On Mon, Oct 5, 2009 at 9:33 PM, Jon <jms480@yahoo. com> wrote:


=A0 

=






yes it causes electronic equipment to malfunction.


Regards,
Jon in =
Texas

                  <p><=
/p><div>It depends on what radiation you're talking about,  the electr=
onic equipment and what it's made of. </div>
<div> </div>
<div>EMP (el=
ectromagnetic pulse) generated at the time of a nuclear detonation will pro=
bably wipe out any solid-state electronics that isn't heavily shielded agai=
nst it. Alpha and beta particles could affect some electronics that managed=
 to survive an EMP.</div>

<div> </div>
<div>The older stuff like RTL =
and TTL logic is probably not going to be much affected by the alpha and be=
ta radiation. CMOS devices, sensitive to static discharges, would be next.&=
nbsp;VLSI chips have the greatest chance of being affected (read: home comp=
uters). Vacuum tube circuits would hardly be affected at all, even by =
EMP.<br>
</div>
